prompt: Hello doctor,I had a question about the ketone diet. I honestly do not understand the benefits of a ketone diet, what are they? Is a ketone diet good for those who are diabetic?
answer: Hello! The main benefit of a ketogenic diet is its ability to help the body enter a state of ketosis, in which it shifts from burning glucose (from carbohydrates) to burning fats for fuel. This can lead to weight loss, improved blood sugar control, and potentially other health benefits such as improved cholesterol and triglycerides levels. For people with diabetes, a ketogenic diet may be helpful in managing blood sugar levels, as it typically involves severely limiting carbohydrate intake. However, it is important to work with a healthcare provider and a registered dietitian to ensure that the diet is tailored to individual needs and does not lead to any adverse effects. It is also important to note that a ketogenic diet is not appropriate for everyone, and should only be considered under the guidance of a healthcare professional.

Other possible causes include anxiety or panic attacks, sleep apnea, or a hiatal hernia. I would recommend speaking to your doctor about your symptoms and discussing the possibility of further testing or treatment for GERD or any other potential underlying conditions.

prompt: Hello doctor,I am 24 years old. For the past two years, I have been having an irregular period cycle. My doctor recently suggested me to get my exam Pap smear. Should I be worried about uterine cervical cancer? I have not lost weight. I do not have pain. I recently had a yeast infection, and I am still healing from that.So when I had intercourse last time I felt a little discomfort in a certain position. I started spoofing today, and I am having normal PMS symptoms sensitive boobs, and I do not bleed in between things. I read that cervical cancer takes 15 years to be invasive, and I am scared.
answer: Hello, I understand your concerns. Pap smear is an important screening test for cervical cancer, especially if you have an irregular menstrual cycle. The purpose of this test is to detect any abnormal changes in the cells of the cervix that could lead to cancer. It's normal to be nervous about a pap smear, but it's a quick and relatively painless test that can help prevent cervical cancer. Weight gain can also affect your menstrual cycle, so it's important to maintain a healthy weight through diet and exercise. If you have concerns about your weight, talk to your doctor about ways to manage it. It's also important to note that not all irregular periods are a sign of cancer. There are many other possible causes, such as hormonal imbalances, thyroid disorders, and polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS). If you have any discomfort during sex, it's important to talk to your doctor about it. It could be related to the yeast infection or other underlying issues that need to be addressed. Cervical cancer does take years to develop, and regular screening can help detect any abnormal changes early on when they are easier to treat. It's important to continue to have regular Pap smears and follow up with your doctor if you have any concerns. In summary, don't be afraid to talk to your doctor about your concerns. Regular screening for cervical cancer and maintaining a healthy lifestyle can help reduce your risk of developing cancer.

prompt: Hi doctor,What is Rhesus? My wife is pregnant and started clinic today.
answer: Hi there! Rhesus, also known as Rh factor, is a protein that is found on the surface of red blood cells. It is important to determine an individual's Rh status, as a person who is Rh-positive has this protein on their red blood cells, while a person who is Rh-negative does not. This information is important during pregnancy because if the mother is Rh-negative and the baby is Rh-positive, there is a risk that the mother's immune system will recognize the baby's Rh-positive blood cells as foreign and mount an immune response against them, which can lead to complications such as hemolytic disease of the newborn. Your wife's clinic will likely test her blood to determine her Rh status and monitor her pregnancy accordingly. Congratulations on your growing family and good luck!

prompt: Hello doctor,In a few sentences, what is the Mediterranean diet? What food categories are typically eaten on the Mediterranean diet? In a few sentences, what health benefits come from the Mediterranean diet? And anything else you would like to add.
answer: The Mediterranean diet is a way of eating inspired by the traditional dietary patterns of the countries surrounding the Mediterranean Sea. It emphasizes whole, plant-based foods such as fruits, vegetables, legumes, whole grains, and nuts, as well as healthy fats such as olive oil and fish. Moderate amounts of dairy products, poultry, and red wine are also included. Research has shown that following a Mediterranean diet may offer a range of health benefits, including reducing the risk of heart disease, certain cancers, and cognitive decline. The Mediterranean diet is also sustainable, with a focus on locally sourced, seasonal foods.

prompt: Hello doctor,I am a 53-year-old male with no previous medical history. For the past two years, I observed my semen to be slightly pinkish in color (now I realized it was due to traces of blood) but I did not pay much attention. Since the last two to three months, I have been seeing blood in my ejaculate specifically if I have sex or masturbate on consecutive days (the second day the amount of blood and redness is much more). If I give a gap of 15-20 days then on the first day I do not see any blood but on the second day, it is quite distinct.I do not feel any sort of pain during or after sex or while masturbation. I do not pass blood in the urine. I do not feel any burning or itching sensation while ejaculating or urinating. I have had no injury in my pelvic area or to my testicles. I do not suffer from diabetes or hypertension. I have been having sex and masturbation two to three times a month. Recently I took Levofloxin 500 OD for six days thinking if it was due to a urinary infection the antibiotic might help but it has not helped. So far I have not consulted any clinician on the subject.
answer: Hello, Based on your symptoms, it is possible that you may have a condition called hematospermia, which is the presence of blood in the ejaculate. Although this condition can be alarming, it is usually not a cause for serious concern in men under the age of 60. The most common causes of hematospermia include infections, inflammation, and trauma to the prostate or other areas in the genital region. Other possible causes include prostate cancer, bladder cancer, and urethral strictures, but these are less common. Since you have already taken an antibiotic without any improvement in your symptoms, it is important that you consult with a healthcare provider for a thorough evaluation. Your clinician may order a semen analysis, blood tests, and imaging studies like ultrasound or MRI to help determine the underlying cause of your hematospermia. Depending on the underlying cause, treatment may involve antibiotics for infections, anti-inflammatory medications for inflammation, or surgery for more serious conditions like prostate or bladder cancer. But the treatment will be determined based on the diagnosis. In summary, it is important that you consult with your clinician for a thorough investigation of your symptoms, since hematospermia may be an early sign of an underlying medical condition that requires treatment.

prompt: Hello doctor,I am wondering if there is any specific thing to look for on an EKG to show bifascicular block? I am trying to learn EKG reading and was wondering if you can help me.
answer: Hi there! Yes, there are certain EKG findings that suggest bifascicular block. Bifascicular block refers to the presence of conduction block in two of the three main conduction pathways in the heart. Specifically, it refers to the combination of right bundle branch block (RBBB) and either left anterior fascicular block (LAFB) or left posterior fascicular block (LPFB).  Some common EKG findings associated with bifascicular block include a widened QRS complex (>120 ms) due to RBBB, as well as abnormal axis deviation due to the LAFB or LPFB.  If the bifascicular block is due to LAFB, the QRS axis may be shifted to the right (i.e. a positively deflected QRS complex in lead II and a negatively deflected QRS complex in lead aVF). On the other hand, if the bifascicular block is due to LPFB, the QRS axis may be shifted to the left (i.e. a negatively deflected QRS complex in lead II and a positively deflected QRS complex in lead aVF).  It's worth noting that bifascicular block can be a tricky diagnosis to make, as other conditions can produce similar EKG findings. In some cases, additional testing such as cardiac imaging or electrophysiological studies may be needed to confirm the diagnosis.  However, as a general rule, if you see a widened QRS complex with abnormal axis deviation, particularly if it's associated with symptoms such as fainting or palpitations, it's important to consider the possibility of bifascicular block and involve a cardiologist in the evaluation.  I hope this helps, and good luck with your EKG studies!

prompt: Hi doctor,I am 32 years old married male. Since two years I am suffering from premature ejaculation. I tried to control it, but did not get better result. My wife is very much unsatisfied. How to cure this issue?
answer: Premature ejaculation is a common problem that can be managed with proper treatment. There are several treatment options available to manage premature ejaculation, including medication, counseling, and behavioral techniques. Medications such as selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs), topical numbing creams, and phosphodiesterase-5 (PDE5) inhibitors can help delay ejaculation. Counseling can help you understand and address any underlying psychological issues that might be contributing to your problem. Behavioral techniques such as the start-stop technique, the squeeze technique, and pelvic floor exercises can also help you delay ejaculation during sex. prompt: Hi doctor,Is it true that you need to expose your face to the sunlight to maintain facial bone structure? Or is it enough to expose the body and the vitamin D distributes all over? Or does it work only in the specific areas where it is actually being produced?

prompt: Hello doctor,I have nerve pain between my left bum and left leg for the past two months. It is so painful that I cannot even walk, sit or lay down.
answer: Hello, I am sorry to hear that you are experiencing such severe pain. There are several possible causes for nerve pain in the buttocks and leg. One possible cause may be sciatica, which occurs when the sciatic nerve, which runs from the lower back down the back of the thigh, becomes irritated or compressed. This can cause pain, tingling, numbness, or weakness in the buttocks and lower leg. Other possible causes include piriformis syndrome, which occurs when the piriformis muscle, which runs from the hip to the back of the thigh, irritates the sciatic nerve; herniated disc, which is a condition in which the cushioning discs between the vertebrae in the spine bulge or rupture and press on a nerve; or spinal stenosis, which is a narrowing of the spinal canal that can put pressure on the nerves. It is important to see a doctor or a healthcare provider for an evaluation, diagnosis, and treatment. They may recommend imaging tests such as an X-ray, CT scan, or MRI to help diagnose the underlying cause of your pain. Treatment options may include medications such as nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs), muscle relaxants, or nerve pain medications; physical therapy or exercises to strengthen the muscles and improve flexibility; or in some cases, surgery.

prompt: Hello doctor,I am a 26 year old male. Fordyce spots with white yellow bumps occur on the edge of my lips.

If you are concerned about the appearance of these spots, you can discuss treatment options with your dermatologist. Some options include topical treatments or laser therapy, but these are typically only done for cosmetic reasons.

Sarcopenia is a common complication of aging and diabetes. It is characterized by the loss of muscle mass and function, leading to decreased mobility and increased risk of falls and fractures. The exact mechanisms underlying sarcopenia in diabetes are not fully understood, but it appears to be related to insulin resistance and chronic inflammation. Management of sarcopenia in diabetes includes regular exercise, balanced nutrition, and adequate glycemic control. Resistance training and aerobic exercise have been shown to be effective in improving muscle mass and strength in people with diabetes. Additionally, a diet rich in lean protein, fruits, vegetables, and whole grains can help maintain muscle mass. It is important for your father to also follow his doctor's recommended treatment plan for his diabetes, which may include medications and regular monitoring of blood glucose levels. Electro homeopathy is not a conventional form of treatment for diabetes and may not have sufficient scientific evidence to support its effectiveness in managing sarcopenia. I would suggest discussing your father's concerns with his doctor and exploring other options for managing his sarcopenia. A registered dietitian or certified diabetes educator may also be able to offer additional guidance on lifestyle modifications that can help improve muscle mass and function. My advice would be to complete the course of antibiotics prescribed by your doctor and then follow up with a fertility specialist to discuss next steps. Treatment includes adopting a gluten-free diet. Without a biopsy, it is possible to miss a diagnosis of celiac disease, and the patient will continue to have symptoms and health issues. Although an endoscopy with biopsy can be uncomfortable, it is a necessary and important procedure. The biopsy will provide valuable information and help your physician make an accurate diagnosis, which is the first step to effective treatment. If you have any concerns or questions about the biopsy, it's best to discuss them with your doctor, who can provide you with more information and guidance.

prompt: Hi doctor,I have been suffering from the derealization symptoms for the past 5 years. I believe they were caused by B12 shots I was taking to treat autism. answer: I'm sorry to hear about your struggles with derealization symptoms. It's possible that your B12 shots and autism may have contributed to these symptoms, but it's also important to consider other factors that could be involved.  You mentioned that your brain scan revealed high inhibition, which could be related to how you process information and perceive the world around you. It's possible that this may be contributing to your derealization symptoms, but more information would be needed to determine this. Adderall and Prozac are medications that are commonly used for ADHD and depression, respectively. While they may be helpful for managing some symptoms, they may not directly target derealization. It's important to work closely with your doctor to find the most effective treatment plan for your specific symptoms and needs. In terms of your dislike for neuroplasticity and dichromatic thinking, it's important to keep an open mind and consider different perspectives. There are many different ways of understanding and experiencing the world, and what works for one person may not work for another. It might be helpful to explore different therapies or approaches that focus on mindfulness, cognitive restructuring, or other techniques that could help with derealization symptoms. Overall, it's important to work closely with a mental health professional who can help you understand and manage your derealization symptoms. They can help you determine the best treatment options for your individual needs and provide ongoing support as you work towards recovery.

prompt: Hello doctor,A dog had bit me in my finger eight years back. At that time I did not take any vaccine or treatment. Is it possible that I can get affected with rabies in the future? What is the diagnosis system of rabies? If I get diagnosed with rabies then what I have to do?
answer: Hello, If a dog had bit you eight years ago and you did not receive any treatment or vaccine, there is a possibility that you could have been infected with rabies. However, it is unlikely that you still have the virus in your system after eight years. Diagnosis of rabies can be done by testing a sample of the animal's brain tissue or through blood tests. If you are diagnosed with rabies, immediate treatment is necessary. There is no cure for rabies once symptoms appear, so the main focus of treatment is to prevent the virus from spreading to the brain. This involves cleaning and disinfecting the wound, receiving a series of vaccinations, and potentially receiving immunoglobulin injections. If you are concerned or experiencing symptoms, please see a healthcare provider as soon as possible.

prompt: Hello doctor,My daughter is 11 years old, height is 5'2" and weight is 45 kg. She started her periods eight months back. It was normal till two months back. She has Iron, vitamin B12, serum ferritin and vitamin D deficiency so gave supplements for the same. Again we went to her around fifteen days later as bleeding was still continuing. She prescribed Trapic for three days and the bleeding stopped but is back again. Today we had gone to the doctor. She has prescribed Regestrone 5 mg thrice a day for a week twice a day and once a day for a week. Please advice. I am concerned about weight gain and other side effects.
answer: Hello. I understand your concern for your daughter's health. Based on the symptoms and medical history you have shared, it seems like your daughter is experiencing irregular periods, which can be caused by a variety of factors such as hormonal imbalances, stress, and underlying medical conditions like polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS). The supplements prescribed for iron, vitamin B12, serum ferritin, and vitamin D deficiencies are essential for maintaining overall health and preventing complications that can arise due to these deficiencies. Regarding the medication prescribed by the gynecologist, Regestrone is a medication that contains norethisterone, which is a synthetic hormone used for menstrual cycle regulation. The medication is given for a limited time and under medical supervision to control abnormal uterine bleeding. Weight gain is a possible side effect of this medication, but it is not necessary for everyone. However, proper diet and exercise can help counteract any weight gain. It is also important to note that your daughter should continue to follow up with her gynecologist regularly to monitor her menstrual cycle, check hormone levels, and detect any underlying medical issues that may require further treatment. I hope this information helps, and please do not hesitate to ask any further questions.

prompt: Hello doctor,I am 6 months pregnant now. Before pregnancy, I have been suffering through allergic rhinitis (sneezing and dry coughing). I wanted to avoid medicines during the first three months of pregnancy but due to late night coughing and phlegm I went to see a gynecologist. At first, she tried to control my cough through a mild cough syrup with ivy leaves but cough does not go away.Then my gynecologist asked me to visit a pulmonologist after a detailed checkup I was diagnosed with bronchial asthma. I do visit my gynecologist for a monthly checkup and she knows that I am taking dry powder inhaler for bronchial asthma. This month my gynecologist advised me to take Rejuva tablet that contains vitamin D and K, it is a kind of nutritional supplement for bone health and Fiore-f tablet for iron deficiency. My Hb is 9 nowadays.My question is
answer: Congratulations on your pregnancy! It is good to hear that your bronchial asthma is under control with the inhalers and Montelukast sodium. It is safe to take iron tablets and nutritional supplements while taking bronchial asthma medicines. In fact, it is important to take them as directed by your doctor to ensure you and your baby receive the necessary nutrients for a healthy pregnancy. Iron supplements may cause minor gastrointestinal side effects like constipation, nausea or stomach upset, but they are not known to cause coughing. It is important to take them with food to minimize these side effects. Regarding your concern about asthma affecting the unborn baby, it is true that poorly controlled asthma during pregnancy can lead to complications like premature birth and low birth weight. However, it sounds like your asthma is well controlled, which is great news. Keep taking your inhalers and seeing your doctor regularly for checkups. Overall, it is important to follow your doctor's advice and take medications as prescribed to ensure both you and your baby stay healthy during pregnancy.

prompt: Hello doctor,My sister is 32 years. After her second birth, she got the problem of diffuse toxic goiter what is called Graves' disease. She is on medication for the last six years. She is on Carbimazole. But, it is not effective as when she stopped taking the medicine she suffers again from the symptoms (heart rate and sweating). The doctor advised her to get treatment by radioactive iodide. But she is worried this can lead to infertility. So, the other choice was to do a surgery to remove the thyroid gland. But, she will be on Thyroxine for the whole life. I wonder if this is the only choice she has. And, if this is the case, what is the best for her as she wants to get pregnant and she is breastfeeding now.Note
answer: Hello, I understand your concern for your sister's condition. Graves' disease is an autoimmune disorder that affects the thyroid gland, leading to the production of excessive thyroid hormones. Carbimazole aims to reduce thyroid hormone synthesis and, hence, relieve the symptoms associated with Graves' disease. However, as you mentioned, it's not effective in your sister's case, and she experiences symptoms when she stops taking it. The two options recommended by the doctor are radioactive iodide treatment or thyroidectomy. Radioactive iodide treatment is a commonly used treatment for Graves' disease that involves administering a dose of radioactive iodide to kill overactive thyroid cells. This treatment is effective in most cases and may have minimal side effects. However, it can lead to hypothyroidism in some cases, and hence, lifelong treatment with Thyroxine may be required. When it comes to fertility, women are advised to avoid pregnancy for at least six months after receiving radioactive iodine treatment. On the other hand, Thyroidectomy, which is the surgical removal of the thyroid gland, may be recommended by the doctor in severe cases. The advantages of thyroidectomy are that it cures hyperthyroidism, and there are no restrictions on pregnancy or breastfeeding. However, as you mentioned, the patient will have to take Thyroxine for the rest of their life. In my opinion, both options have their advantages and disadvantages, and the best approach depends on the severity of your sister's condition and her preferences. If your sister wants to get pregnant soon or is currently breastfeeding, she may prefer to go for a thyroidectomy as it does not have any impact on fertility, and she can continue breastfeeding. However, if she is willing to wait for six months to plan her pregnancy, radioactive iodine treatment may be more effective. I would suggest discussing the pros and cons of both treatments with a specialist in Endocrinology, who can guide her to make an informed decision that's best suited for her comprehensive health. I hope this helps.

prompt: Hello doctor,I am interested in LASIK laser. My eye side number is R = - 1.75 and L = -2.25. My cornea focus is 590 590. Please advise me a little bit about what to do about customise Vs. bladeless technique surgery.
answer: Hello! LASIK surgery is a popular and effective method of correcting vision problems such as myopia (nearsightedness), hyperopia (farsightedness), and astigmatism. Customized LASIK and bladeless LASIK are two different techniques used to perform this procedure.  Customized LASIK, also known as Wavefront-guided LASIK, uses advanced computer technology to create a 3D map of your eye. This map is used to guide the laser during the procedure, resulting in a more personalized and precise treatment. This technique is often recommended for patients with unique visual aberrations such as higher-order aberrations. Bladeless LASIK, also known as Femtosecond LASIK, uses a specialized laser to create a corneal flap instead of using a blade. The laser creates microscopic bubbles within the cornea, which allows for a more precise and consistent corneal flap creation. This technique is generally considered to be safer and more precise than traditional LASIK, which uses a blade to create the corneal flap. It is important to discuss these options with your LASIK surgeon to determine which technique is best for you based on your specific individual needs and visual aberrations. They can conduct a thorough eye exam and provide guidance on the best course of action for your eyes.

prompt: Hello,I am writing to ask about some symptoms I have been experiencing. I am 57 years old. For almost a week I havehad persistent low grade fever (never more than 100.5). After the end of the week, today I no longer has a fever. We did a blood test and found abnormally low amount of platelets
answer: Hello, Thank you for sharing your concerns with me. It is understandable that you are worried considering the low platelet count. A low platelet count, also known as thrombocytopenia, means that you have reduced blood clotting ability, which can lead to symptoms like easy bruising, bleeding gums, nosebleeds, and in severe cases, internal bleeding. There are several causes of thrombocytopenia, including viral infections, autoimmune disorders, medication side effects, liver or kidney disease, and, in rare cases, cancer or bone marrow disorders. Given the history of the recent low-grade fever, it's possible that the drop in platelet count may be due to a viral infection. However, other causes need to be ruled out as well. I would advise you to schedule an appointment with your healthcare provider, who may want to investigate further with additional blood tests and a physical examination to determine the root cause. They may also refer you to a hematologist for further evaluation. I hope this helps, and I wish you a speedy recovery. Please take care.

prompt: Hi doctor,I am 22 years old. My height is 5'11" and weight is 100 kg. I had a condom on and I did not know that she was on her period. As there was blood on the condom, I removed it and had a new one. We had sexual intercourse again and again until she was bleeding badly. As far as I remember, the condom did not break both times. But, she cleaned her vagina and without proper washing she gave handjob and I ejaculated.Can I get HIV from the above act? Is there any possibility that the virus transmitted with her hand to my penis as her hands could have period blood on them and there was no lubricant involved while handjob? If so, what is the risk probability? Can blood on the condom somehow get to the foreskin of the penis? Could that blood transmit HIV?The exposure happened 48 hours ago and started PEP after 7 hours of exposure. I am on Tafero EM and Ritocom. Am I taking the correct medicine? Am I safe?
answer: As long as the condoms did not break or fail, the risk of HIV transmission during vaginal intercourse is very low. However, HIV can be present in menstrual blood, so there is a theoretical risk of transmission even if the condoms did not break. Regarding the handjob, the risk of HIV transmission through this activity is also very low, but it is not zero. The risk is higher if there are open wounds, cuts or sores on the penis or hand. However, the likelihood of transmission through this activity is significantly lower compared to vaginal intercourse. PEP is recommended as a preventive measure in cases of potential exposure to HIV. You have started PEP within 72 hours of exposure, which is the recommended timeframe. Tafero EM and Ritocom are commonly used medicines for HIV post-exposure prophylaxis. It is important to note that PEP is not 100% effective and does not guarantee protection against HIV transmission. Additionally, PEP may cause side effects such as nausea, headache, and fatigue. It is important to continue taking your medication as prescribed and to follow up with your healthcare provider regularly during and after the PEP course. In summary, while the risk of transmission from the activities you described is low, it is not zero. PEP can reduce the risk of HIV transmission, and you have taken the appropriate steps by starting PEP within the recommended timeframe. However, it is still important to practice safe sex and get regular HIV testing in the future.

The main problem is that we failed to understand whether my baby is hungry or she is sleepy as in both the cases baby sucks her finger. answer: Hello! As your pediatrician has suggested, it is important to get some basic tests done to rule out any underlying medical conditions that could be affecting your baby's feeding and weight gain. Regarding your concerns about your baby's feeding schedule and formula, it is normal for babies to have varied feeding patterns and to occasionally refuse feedings due to sleepiness. It is important to offer the bottle frequently (every 2-3 hours) to ensure that your baby is getting enough nutrition. If your baby is not finishing the bottle, it may be helpful to try a smaller bottle or switch to a slower flow nipple to make it easier for her to consume the milk. Regarding changing formula, it is generally not recommended to switch back and forth between different brands or types of formula. However, if you are considering a change, it is important to consult with your pediatrician to determine which formula would be best for your baby. Dexolac 1 is a good option, but it is important to follow your doctor's recommendation. If your baby is sleeping for more than 4 hours at a time, it is generally okay to let her sleep. However, it is important to ensure that she is feeding frequently during the day to ensure that she is getting enough nutrition. If you are concerned about your baby's weight gain, it may be helpful to wake her for a feeding during the night. I hope this helps! prompt: Hello doctor,I am concerned that my son may have Lyme disease or Skeeter's syndrome. I have several pictures of the area. Site description
answer: Hello! Thank you for sharing your concerns. Based on the information provided, it is difficult to make a definitive diagnosis without physically examining your son. Skeeter's syndrome, on the other hand, is an allergic reaction to mosquito bites. The affected area can be red, swollen, and warm to the touch. Other symptoms can include fever and decreased activity. Given that your son has a fever, decreased activity, and a red and swollen area with warmth around the bites, I would recommend having him evaluated by a healthcare provider in-person. prompt: Hello doctor,I have had POTS syndrome for 5 years and recently had loop recorder implanted. I have been told that I have atrial tachycardia and need ablation. Will ablation make POTS worse?
answer: Ablation for atrial tachycardia should not make POTS worse, in fact, it may help improve symptoms. Atrial tachycardia is a fast heartbeat that starts in the upper chambers of the heart (atria). An ablation procedure for atrial tachycardia involves using catheters to deliver energy to the areas of the heart where the abnormal electrical signals are generated, in order to eliminate them. POTS syndrome is characterized by an increased heart rate upon standing, resulting in symptoms such as dizziness, lightheadedness, and fainting. Although the two conditions are different, ablation for atrial tachycardia could help stabilize heart rhythm and improve blood flow, potentially reducing symptoms of POTS.  It is important to discuss any concerns about how the ablation procedure may affect your POTS symptoms with your doctor.

If you miss your period, it is always best to take a pregnancy test to confirm.

prompt: Hello doctor,Is a 600 cc breast implant the same as a 500 cc implant filled to 600 cc? Is a 500 cc implant filled to 600 cc considered extremely large with more chance of rupture? Is going from A cup to C cup (350 cc) then going from C cup to possible D cup (500 cc filled to 600 cc) that big of a difference?
answer: Hello, A 600 cc breast implant is not the same as a 500 cc implant filled to 600 cc. The former is a true 600 cc implant and the latter is a 500 cc implant overfilled with saline to 600 cc. Overfilling an implant can decrease its lifespan and increase the risk of rupture, but this is generally safe to do within the manufacturer's recommended limits (usually 10-20% overfill).  A 500 cc implant filled to 600 cc is considered a large implant, but it is not overly large or risky if done within the limits described above. However, larger implants do come with increased risks of complications like implant displacement and sagging, and they may not be recommended for all patients depending on their anatomy and lifestyle.  Going from an A cup to a C cup with a breast implant size of 350 cc is a moderate increase in breast size, while going from a C cup to a D cup with a breast implant size of 500 cc filled to 600 cc is a noticeable increase in size. However, the exact appearance of the final result will depend on factors like your natural breast size and shape, underlying chest anatomy, and the placement and type of implant chosen. Your plastic surgeon can help guide you in selecting the appropriate implant size based on your aesthetic goals and individual needs.

prompt: Hello doctor,I am a 21-year-old male and I weigh 57 Kg. I am 5 feet 6 inches in height. My symptoms are a cough for one month. I am currently on tablet Levosure 500 mg, tablet Ventair 10 mg, and syrup Adovas. Please help.

prompt: Hello doctor,I suffer from an L5-S1 disc hernia, with pressure on the S1 root. I also have a partial tear in the right hip labrum. My surgeon is not sure which one is the cause of leg pain which starts at the low back and ends at the back of my feet. I suffer from a great deal of pain and would really like to get it over with.
answer: I'm sorry to hear about your condition. Determining whether the L5-S1 disc herniation or the partial tear in your hip labrum is causing your leg pain can be difficult. Further diagnostic tests such as an MRI, CT scan, or nerve conduction study may be necessary to determine which condition is causing your pain. In the meantime, there are several ways you can manage your pain. Your doctor may recommend physical therapy, stretching exercises, or anti-inflammatory medications. Heat or ice therapy may also provide some relief. If your pain is severe and does not respond to conservative treatment methods, surgery may be an option. However, this is typically only recommended if all other options have been exhausted. It's important to have an open and honest discussion with your doctor about the best course of treatment for your condition. Remember to be patient and persistent in managing your pain, as it can take time to find the right treatment plan.

prompt: Hello doctor,I would like to know, can cortisone help if taken before transferring an embryo? And if it can help so, in which way?
answer: There is some evidence that suggests that taking cortisone (also known as prednisone) before embryo transfer may improve pregnancy rates in women undergoing in vitro fertilization (IVF) treatment. Cortisone is a type of steroid that can reduce inflammation in the body and suppress the immune system.  In some cases, fertility specialists may prescribe cortisone before embryo transfer to help suppress immune system activity and prevent the body from rejecting the embryo. This is particularly true for women who have a history of autoimmune disorders or recurrent IVF failure. However, it's important to note that taking cortisone is not a standard part of IVF treatment and should only be used under the close guidance of a healthcare professional. Cortisone can have side effects, including weight gain, mood changes, increased blood sugar levels, and increased risk of infections. If you're considering taking cortisone before embryo transfer, it's essential to discuss the risks and benefits with your doctor to determine if it's the right treatment option for you.

prompt: Hi doctor,After deep brain stimulation surgery for generalized dystonia 18 months ago, I have developed mild startle myoclonus a fortnight later and was prescribed 0.5 mg Clonazepam. Since being on Clonazepam, I developed mild anxiety and my myoclonus continued to worsen. Now, I have violent full body jerks that cause me to fall over backwards every day. I am now on 1 mg Clonazepam in the morning and evening. After six months of Clonazepam and just after increasing my dose to 0.5 mg twice a day, I developed pressure of speech and the longer I have been on the drug the worse my myoclonus and anxiety has become. I am now in a vicious circle as the myoclonus episodes are so violent and I fall backwards heavily despite whatever I hold onto. I have become anxious at having an episode and the actual anxiety can trigger a myoclonus episode, although it also occurs when I feel safe such as sitting down, reading a book or chatting with friends.Six weeks ago, I was told to double the dose due to the high number of falls I was having during myoclonus episodes and since then I have developed mini-seizures and worsening of anxiety. My neurologist is referring me to a psychiatrist for CBT for anxiety and now believes anxiety is the likely cause of my myoclonus. I am happy to do this as I just want to overcome my fear of falling. My dystonia also is causing me to fall due to motor control problems with my legs. The behavior of my legs is very unpredictable, so without warning I regularly trip or my legs suddenly buckle, especially when tired or if I am on my feet for too long. Every drug I have been on since been diagnosed with dystonia has caused serious side effects, even at a low dose and I was told by one of the neurologists that my brain is very sensitive to the side effects of the drugs. The anxiety has only developed since being on the Clonazepam and seems to have worsened whenever the dose has been increased. Could Clonazepam cause anxiety?I have now lost my confidence to leave the house, even with my walker as during a myoclonus episode it is so vigorous the walker just tips over with me and I have episodes every day, but just do not know when one may occur. I have not walked as far as the end of my road about 100 meters for nearly five months now and even with friends still feel apprehensive when walking even a short distance with them. I have lost my confidence to stand in the kitchen to do chores in case I have an episode. I often crawl around on the floor, especially when tired as tiredness definitely increases the episodes and the higher dosage of Clonazepam makes me feel very tired by midday.I am also under stress at home as I am a carer of my 86 year old father who has Alzheimer's, although I get some support from social services with carers, who come in to get him up and his breakfast and then his evening meal. I am normally a very positive person, but right now I wonder if I will ever get better. I am keen to start CBT. But, I am still concerned that Clonazepam initiated the anxiety as a side effect and so would need to withdraw from the Clonazepam in order to recover properly. All I know for certain is I never had myoclonus before my DBS surgery. I never had anxiety or a single fall. Right now, I wish I never had DBS as it done little to help me physically and my quality of life right now is far worse. I am finding it hard to stay positive and feel very discouraged. Please help me.
answer: I am sorry to hear about the difficulties you have been experiencing. It is possible that Clonazepam may have contributed to or exacerbated your anxiety. Withdrawal from Clonazepam should be done very gradually and under close medical supervision to avoid seizures and other withdrawal symptoms. Before you start CBT, it may be helpful to discuss your concerns about Clonazepam with your neurologist or a psychiatrist who can help you develop an appropriate tapering schedule if needed. They can also evaluate if there are any other medications that may be contributing to your symptoms or that may be helpful for your myoclonus or dystonia. It is important to have a comprehensive evaluation by a neurologist and a psychiatrist to determine the most appropriate treatment for your symptoms. In addition to medication and CBT, you may also benefit from physical therapy, occupational therapy, or other interventions that can help improve motor control and reduce falls. Please talk to your healthcare team about your concerns and explore all the options available to you.

prompt: Hello doctor,I am having high and low fever for the past few days and starting from yesterday, I have sore throat. I went to pee just now and saw the color is a bit reddish brown. And one week before fever, I had a few mosquito bites which are itchy on both the legs.

prompt: Hi doctor,I have been having difficulties breathing. It feels like mucus is blocking my airways. I also have this feeling that something is stuck in my throat. I did a thyroid blood test, TSH, and T3 which were normal but T4 was high. I did thyroid scan, it showed a soft cyst of 10 mm 'xc3'x97 8 mm in my left lobe and another one in my isthmus about 6 mm. I am having a serious stomach acid, heart palpitations, irregular heartbeat, and my pause ranges between 40 to 45 each time I check it. I always feel hot, feel tired easily when doing a hard job. I would like to know if I have hyperthyroidism and for the cyst, do you think I need a surgery or is my problem something which medication can solve.
answer: Based on your symptoms and thyroid test results, it is possible that you have hyperthyroidism. The presence of thyroid nodules or cysts does not necessarily indicate that surgery is necessary. In some cases, medication can be used to manage symptoms and shrink the nodules. However, since the cysts are relatively large, your doctor may recommend a biopsy to rule out the possibility of thyroid cancer.  Your stomach acid, heart palpitations, and irregular heartbeat may also be related to your thyroid condition. Treatment of hyperthyroidism may help to alleviate these symptoms. Your low heart rate may be a result of medication, but it could also be an indication of a heart problem. Your doctor may recommend further evaluation, such as an electrocardiogram or echocardiogram, to assess your heart health.  It is important to discuss these concerns with your healthcare provider, who can recommend appropriate testing and treatment options to help alleviate your symptoms.

prompt: Hello doctor,My father is a heart patient and his ejection fraction is 35 %. He is now suffering from kidney stone which is currently stuck in the penis. answer: Hello, I understand your concerns. If the kidney stone is stuck in the penis causing obstruction of urine flow, a catheterization can indeed be attempted to relieve the obstruction. However, if the catheterization fails, surgical intervention may become necessary to remove the stone. The decision regarding the use of anesthesia should be made by the managing team, taking all factors including your father's cardiac condition into consideration. It is important to manage the kidney stone as soon as possible, as any urinary obstruction can lead to further complications. Additionally, his medications for heart disease should be continued as prescribed. I recommend speaking to your father's healthcare team to discuss the best course of action for your father's situation, given his medical history and current condition.

prompt: Hello doctor, I am 18 years old. Today I finally got the courage to talk to my doctor about the stress obsessive thoughts, and the physical harm it does to me. I got an appointment with a psychologist. She diagnosed me with anxiety, panic disorder, and being severe hyperemotional. The doctor did not want me to go to a psychiatrist because he might give me medication that would be addictive, and affect my learning skills. I have exams very soon, so they try to help me in some other ways, but I tried these before without any good. What should I do? I cannot deal with the obsessive feelings, crying, trembling all the time, digestive problems, and everything that comes with these disorders every day.
answer: First of all, it's great that you reached out for help and that you have been diagnosed with anxiety and panic disorder by a psychologist. It's important to understand that anxiety and panic disorders are medical conditions that require professional care. So, it's good that you are seeing a psychologist. It's understandable to have concerns about medication side effects, but medication can be very helpful for managing anxiety disorders. It's important to remember that psychiatrists are medical doctors who specialize in mental health, and they have extensive training and experience in prescribing medication. If you are uncomfortable with the idea of medication or if it is not an option at this time, there are other ways to manage anxiety. Therapy such as cognitive-behavioral therapy (CBT) can be very helpful in managing anxiety symptoms. CBT focuses on identifying and changing negative thoughts and behaviors. Other self-help strategies that may be helpful include deep breathing exercises, yoga, meditation, exercise, and stress management techniques. It may be helpful to talk to your psychologist about these options. It's important to remember that managing anxiety can be a process and it may take time to find what works best for you. Be patient with yourself and don't give up hope. With the help of a professional and self-care strategies, it is possible to manage anxiety and live a fulfilling life.

prompt: Hi doctor,We are not willing to use a condom. We want a natural sex without a condom. In such conditions, women take pills after sex to prevent pregnancy. But we want a pill taken before sex which can prevent pregnancy guaranteed. Is there any pill taken before sex to prevent pregnancy? Which is the best one? How much should be taken and how much time should be taken before having sex?
answer: There are contraceptive pills that can be taken before sex to prevent pregnancy, but such pills are not recommended as a standard contraceptive method. The regular use of such pills can have serious health consequences, including liver damage or blood clots.  Moreover, there are no guarantees that before-sex pills will always prevent pregnancy. In order to minimize the chance of pregnancy, it is important to consistently use a reliable contraceptive method. If you are not willing to use condoms, you could consider discussing with your healthcare provider about alternative methods of contraception, such as the birth control pill, an intrauterine device (IUD), or a contraceptive implant, depending on your individual circumstances and medical history.

prompt: Hi doctor,I took the first abortion pill but until now, I did not get bleed. What is the reason?
answer: There are several reasons why you may not have experienced bleeding after taking the first abortion pill.  Firstly, the bleeding may not start immediately after taking the pill. It can take up to 48 hours or longer for the bleeding to start. Secondly, if you took the first abortion pill within 24 hours of your missed period, you may not experience bleeding as your period may have already been on its way. Thirdly, there is a possibility that the first pill did not work as it should have. In this case, you should speak with your healthcare provider regarding further treatment. Finally, some women may experience minimal or no bleeding at all. This is a rare occurrence but can sometimes happen. It is important to follow up with your healthcare provider to discuss any concerns or questions you may have regarding your abortion process.

prompt: Hello doctor,I am a female nearing 40. My partner and I are sexually very active. A year ago, I was diagnosed for PID, and pap smear revealed nothing else. We both got treated and were fine for a few months. I am very clean, often wash before and after the act. We are both into oral too. Since a few days, I am having excessive discharge (no smell or pus) which is almost white, burning at the tip of my left labia and pain in the lower abdomen.There is no burning sensation when I pass urine. After meeting the burn comes up. I do not use perfumed soaps, but I use a feminine wash. Is this PID again or something else? My partner is fine, and we use protection during this time. Can you suggest some medication? And what could this be?
answer: Hello. From what you have described, it is possible that you may have a recurrent pelvic inflammatory disease (PID) or a vaginal infection like bacterial vaginosis or yeast infection. These conditions can cause symptoms such as excessive discharge, burning or itching in the genital area, and lower abdominal pain.  I recommend that you see a healthcare provider for an evaluation, especially if these symptoms persist or worsen. They will do a physical examination and may recommend tests such as a vaginal swab, urine test, or ultrasound if needed. Treatment for PID or other vaginal infections may involve antibiotics or antifungal medication, depending on the specific diagnosis. It is important that your partner gets tested and treated as well, even if he is asymptomatic.  In the meantime, avoid using any feminine wash or douching as these can disrupt the natural balance of bacteria in the vagina and worsen symptoms. Wear cotton underwear and avoid tight clothing to help with ventilation. Over-the-counter pain relievers like acetaminophen or ibuprofen may help with the abdominal pain.  Take care and do not hesitate to seek professional medical attention.

prompt: Hello doctor,I am a 33 year old female. I got my cavity filled two days back. Now, it hurts when I drink cold stuff. Is there anything I can do?
answer: Hello, it is common to experience sensitivity after filling a cavity. This usually resolves on its own within a few weeks. However, you can try to ease the discomfort by avoiding hot or cold foods, using a desensitizing toothpaste and taking over-the-counter pain relievers like ibuprofen. It’s also important to inform your dentist about your symptoms to rule out any complications.

prompt: Hi doctor,10 days ago I had oral sex with CSW while drunk. I visited the GP the next day who gave me PEP, now nine days. Yesterday, I saw a hairy black tongue and freaked out. Visited local clinic, was prescribed mouthwash and Miconazole cream and did HIV 1 and 2 antibodies, due, hep B and VDRL- all negative.Also saw a small purple patch on the right forearm. I am not sleeping, worried sick.I want to know the risk of HIV and if confirmed very low, what is probably going on with black tongue and a purple patch on the skin. Intend to get the HIV PCR test done in RSA on day 13. Please advise.
answer: I am sorry to hear about your experience. Firstly, the PEP medication that you were given is highly effective in reducing the risk of HIV transmission when taken correctly. In fact, studies have shown that PEP can reduce the risk of HIV transmission by over 80%. As for the black tongue and purple patch on your skin, it is difficult for me to make a diagnosis without actually seeing them. These symptoms could be caused by a number of different things, including fungal or bacterial infections, or even just changes in your oral hygiene habits. It is good that you have already seen a healthcare provider and had some tests done. The fact that your HIV, hep B, and VDRL tests were negative is a very good sign. As for the HIV PCR test, this can provide an early indication of whether or not someone has been infected with HIV. However, it is important to note that HIV can take up to 6 weeks or longer to show up on standard HIV tests, so it is possible that you may need to be retested later on. It is understandable that you are feeling worried and anxious at this time. However, it is important to remember that you have taken steps to reduce your risk of HIV transmission and have already had some tests done, which have come back negative. I would advise you to continue following up with your healthcare provider, and to try to focus on taking care of your mental and emotional health during this stressful time.

prompt: Hi doctor,Approximately six weeks ago, I got niggling wisdom teeth pain. The left top and bottom wisdom teeth were breaking through the gums. I got sudden pain which was severe in intensity around the back of my mouth and the lower left side. It got aggravated especially on chewing and radiating to the next tooth and along the jaw. The dentist suggested a wait and watch for few days. The next day when the wisdom tooth started to come out, the pain got severely worse over the jaw and the temporomandibular joint. I was unable to tolerate. I cannot even rest my top and bottom teeth together. I got complete numbness on the left side of the chin and lower lip and difficulty in opening my mouth for more than one or two fingers. I could not sleep and felt ill because of the pain. On the X-ray, the wisdom tooth is horizontally impacted, and there were no signs of infection or abscess. The tooth next to the wisdom has a large old filling nearing the pulp. But there are no signs of anything wrong with it on an X-ray. The dentists could not find whether it was the pressure of the impacted tooth on the next tooth or problem with the filled tooth. So, I was just given antibiotics. By the end of the antibiotics, it was slightly better, but I still felt ill. Again, the dentist decided to wait and watch. As I felt iller than the previous time, I was given another course of different antibiotics. The pain was reduced. But I still have numbness in the chin. However, most of the numbness on the lip has resolved.A constant cramp sensation along the bottom of my jaw and temporomandibular joint with the discomfort temporarily ease with rubbing or stretching or massage. I regained most of my mouth opening back, but it is uncomfortable to open and hold in that position. I also think the jaw discomfort and cramping are worse on the days when I have to talk more. The wisdom tooth and the next tooth are still mildly tender. I can eat soft foods comfortably, but I get pain in the two teeth and the gum surrounding the wisdom tooth on eating hard foods like a raw carrot. The pain will last up to an hour or more. I have never had any hot or cold sensitivity or nasty taste in my mouth. The dentist I saw thinks that it is because of the nerves from the filled tooth and wants to do root canal treatment or extraction. How would this change any of the nerve or temporomandibular joint pain? I am worried that if the impacted tooth's pressure is causing the pain, then it will make no difference anyway. Do you know a way to differentiate? Which do you think is the more likely cause?
answer: Based on your description, it seems that the impacted wisdom tooth may be the primary cause for your pain and discomfort. The pressure from the impacted tooth could be causing inflammation and nerve irritation, leading to the numbness and discomfort you are experiencing in your chin and temporomandibular joint. However, the filling in the adjacent tooth could also be contributing to the discomfort and may need attention. If the dentist is recommending root canal treatment or extraction for the filled tooth, it is likely that they believe the filling is contributing to your symptoms. If the filling is causing the nerve irritation, addressing it through root canal treatment or extraction may help to alleviate your nerve and jaw pain. However, it is important to keep in mind that the impacted wisdom tooth may also need to be addressed to completely resolve your symptoms. Depending on the severity of impaction and proximity to surrounding nerves, the tooth may need to be surgically removed to alleviate pressure and inflammation. It may be helpful to seek a second opinion from a specialist such as an oral surgeon who can evaluate both the impacted wisdom tooth and the filled tooth to determine the best course of treatment.

prompt: Hello doctor,My 4-year-old child has caries on teeth. Since one year we observed pus in the gums above the front tooth. This pus frequently appears with mild pain and disappears within no time. We consulted a doctor who prescribed antibiotic Mox Kid for a week. After using this, again pus was found in the next 10 days.It is in the same place frequently observed. Please advise.
answer: Hello, It sounds like your child has an abscessed tooth. This can occur when there is untreated dental decay that has progressed and infected the pulpal tissue, which is the nerve and blood vessels inside the tooth. The pus you are seeing is a sign of an infection. Antibiotics alone will not treat the underlying problem, which is the decayed tooth. Ideally, your child should be seen by a pediatric dentist. They can examine the tooth and provide treatment options, such as a filling, a temporary or permanent crown, or a root canal. If the decay is too extensive, the tooth may need to be extracted. In the meantime, you can rinse your child's mouth with warm salt water several times a day to help reduce swelling and discomfort. Over-the-counter pain relief medication can also be given, but only after consulting with your child's pediatrician. It is important to get this issue addressed promptly, as untreated dental infections can lead to serious complications.

prompt: Dear doctor,I am a 19 year old male. Some type of viscous liquid comes out of my ears and when it dries up, it hardens. Please help me.
answer: It sounds like you may be experiencing a buildup of cerumen or earwax. This is a natural substance produced by the body to protect the ear canal from dirt and debris. However, if it accumulates to excess, it can cause blockages and other problems. I would recommend making an appointment with your doctor or an ear, nose, and throat specialist. They can properly examine your ears and determine the cause of the discharge. In some cases, they may need to remove the excess wax manually. In the meantime, avoid using cotton swabs or other objects to try and clean your ears, as this can push the wax deeper into the canal and cause further complications. Additionally, avoid using earplugs or headphones until you've received a proper diagnosis and treatment plan.

prompt: Hi doctor,I am 21 years old. I have muscle weakness in both arms and legs since childhood. I cannot climb stairs without support and I feel tired most of the day. I cannot stand for long and also cannot run or walk. My legs and feet always get numb. I have decreased sensory sensations in both feet. A few months back, I was diagnosed with hypothyroidism and vitiligo. I visited a doctor last month. My EMG and nerve conduction study shows symmetrical sensory motor demyelinating polyneuropathy with clinical diagnosis of CIDP. CPK is 227 (reference range 24-195 U/L). I am on Prednisolone 45 mg, Levothyroxine 100 mcg and multivitamins for the past 17 days. Please guide me about my disease, prognosis and any rehabilitation that might help.
answer: Based on your symptoms, medical history, and test results, it appears that you have chronic inflammatory demyelinating polyneuropathy (CIDP). This is a rare autoimmune condition that affects the peripheral nerves and causes muscle weakness, numbness, and tingling in the arms and legs. The good news is that CIDP can be treated with medications, such as corticosteroids and immunosuppressants, which can help to reduce inflammation and slow down the progression of the disease. However, it is important to note that there is no cure for CIDP, and treatment may need to be continued for a long period of time. In addition to medication, physical therapy and rehabilitation can also be helpful in managing CIDP. These interventions can help to improve and maintain muscle function, increase mobility, and prevent falls and other complications. prompt: Hi doctor,I have small colorless bumps on my arm and a couple on fingers of my hand. They do not cause any pain or itching. But, I have noticed that they were not present on my arm earlier, and I would like to avoid these spreading elsewhere. Kindly suggest the causes and treatment.
answer: Hi! From your description, it is possible that these bumps are a type of skin condition called molluscum contagiosum. It is caused by a virus and can be spread from person to person through skin-to-skin contact, sharing items like towels or clothing, or even from touching surfaces that have the virus on them. The good news is that it is usually a harmless condition and often clears up on its own within a few months to a year. However, you may want to consider seeing a dermatologist who can recommend treatment options to help eliminate the bumps and prevent them from spreading. Treatment options may include cryotherapy (freezing the bumps off), topical creams or ointments, or other procedures. It's important to avoid scratching or picking at the bumps as this can spread the virus and lead to scarring. In addition to seeking medical advice, you can also take steps to prevent the spread of the virus by washing your hands regularly, avoiding sharing personal items, and avoiding skin-to-skin contact with others until the bumps have cleared up.

Please consult with your healthcare provider as soon as possible to complete your PEP regimen and receive any additional medical care recommended for your wound.

prompt: Hello doctor,After three miscarriages, my doctor suggested me for torch test and it came out positive with high values of rubella IgG 272, toxoplasma IgG 78.6 and CMV IgG 12.1 and herpes IgG 46.1. answer: Hello! It sounds like you have been through a difficult journey with multiple miscarriages. The torch test is done to check for any infections that may be causing the miscarriages. The positive IgG values indicate that you have been exposed to these infections at some point in the past, but the normal IgM values suggest that you do not currently have an active infection. The medication you have been prescribed, Acylex (acyclovir), is an antiviral medication used to treat herpes infections. It may also be used to suppress viral shedding, which can help reduce the transmission of herpes to a sexual partner. It is not typically used to treat the other infections detected by the torch test. It's important to keep in mind that a positive torch test does not necessarily mean that you will have another miscarriage. Many women with positive torch test results go on to have healthy pregnancies. However, it is important to monitor the pregnancy carefully with regular prenatal care, including ultrasound exams and possibly additional testing or treatment if needed. Your doctor may want to do further testing, such as checking for an active infection with other types of tests, or repeating the torch test again in the future. They may also want to refer you to a specialist, such as a maternal-fetal medicine doctor or infectious disease specialist, to help manage your care. As for when to plan a pregnancy, it's best to discuss this with your doctor. They can help you weigh the risks and benefits and make a plan that is tailored to your specific situation. Depending on the results of further testing, your doctor may recommend waiting a certain amount of time before trying to conceive again. prompt: Hello doctor,What is the stigma around mental health? Why it is there? How can people help break the stigma around mental health and what advice do you have for people who want help but stigma is keeping them from getting it?
answer: Hello,  Stigma around mental health refers to the negative attitudes, beliefs, and stereotypes that people hold about individuals who are experiencing mental health disorders. This stigma can prevent people from seeking treatment and support, creating significant barriers to recovery and wellbeing. The stigma around mental health exists due to a lack of understanding, fears, and misconceptions about mental health conditions. To break the stigma around mental health, we need to start having open and honest conversations about mental health and mental illness. We need to educate ourselves and others on the realities of mental health disorders and work to dispel myths and stereotypes. We need to promote empathy and understanding towards those who have mental health challenges, and support them in seeking professional help. For those who are struggling with stigma and are afraid to seek help, it is important to know that mental health disorders are common and treatable. Asking for help is not a sign of weakness, but rather a courageous step towards healing and recovery. Seek support from loved ones, peers, or professionals who specialize in mental health care. Find a therapist or a support group that can help you to build a support network and navigate the challenges of living with a mental health disorder. Remember, you are not alone in your struggles with mental health. There is hope, and with the right support, you can take control of your mental health and move towards a happier, healthier future.

prompt: Hello doctor,I have a wrist pain on the top of it. Usually, when I use it in daily life it is all nice but as soon as I even swing a tennis racquet soon afterward pain develops. answer: Based on your description, it is possible that you have a condition called tennis elbow or lateral epicondylitis. Although it is called tennis elbow, it can occur in anyone who performs repetitive gripping or wrist extension activities, such as playing tennis or using a computer mouse. The pain typically occurs on the outside of the elbow and can radiate down into the forearm, making it difficult to grip or lift objects.  In your case, the wrist pain on top and inability to pronate may be related to compensating for the discomfort in your elbow. It's important to have a proper diagnosis from a doctor or physical therapist to rule out other possible causes of wrist pain. Treatment for tennis elbow typically involves rest, ice, physical therapy, and stretching exercises, and potentially the use of a brace to support the joint. Anti-inflammatory medication or injections may also provide relief. In some cases, surgery may be necessary. I would recommend seeking medical attention to determine the best course of treatment for your condition.

prompt: Hello doctor,As bisexuality is defined as attraction to both men and women, however, many men who feel that way tend to not identify as that. Please explain why this is? And, why bisexuality among men has been so stigmatized in the past? And why it has not seemed to improve, even as people become more accepting of homosexuality?
answer: There are several reasons why some men who are attracted to both men and women may not identify as bisexual. One reason is that bisexuality is still stigmatized and discriminated against in many societies, which can make individuals feel ashamed, afraid, or confused about their attraction towards both genders. They may fear judgment from friends, family, and society in general, and may therefore find it easier to identify as straight or gay instead. Moreover, men who are attracted to both men and women may also feel that their same-sex attraction is not strong enough to warrant the label "bisexual." They may believe that they are "mostly straight" or "mostly gay," or that their attraction to one gender is stronger than their attraction to the other. Bisexuality among men has been stigmatized in the past due to societal norms, gender roles, and religious beliefs. In many societies, men are expected to be masculine, assertive, and dominant, especially in their sexual relationships. Homosexuality and bisexuality are often seen as threats to this norm, leading to social discrimination and marginalization. Furthermore, the common misconception that bisexuality is a transitional phase or a stepping stone towards homosexuality has also contributed to the stigmatization of bisexuality among men. This stereotype is not only invalid but also perpetuates the idea that bisexuality is not a valid sexual orientation. While people are becoming more accepting of homosexuality, bisexuality still faces a lot of stigma and discrimination. This is because bisexuality challenges traditional norms, and many people find it difficult to understand or accept attractions outside of the norm. Moreover, bisexual individuals are often also marginalized within the LGBTQ+ community, leading to further social and emotional challenges. Nonetheless, there have been increasing efforts to raise awareness and visibility around bisexuality, and to promote greater acceptance and understanding of this valid sexual orientation.

prompt: Hi doctor,I am a 33 year old female. I have never smoked. I am not overweight and I do not have diabetes. I have been having some left leg issues. It started six months back. I started limping because my left calf, ankle and groin were hurting. My emergency Doppler venous ultrasound was clear. I had a D-dimer and that was negative. I had an MRI of my left ankle that showed a talofibular ligament sprain on my left ankle. I also had an arterial Doppler ultrasound that showed decreased flow of left anterior tibial artery and increased peak systolic velocity in the left common femoral artery. But, there was no stenosis, no sclerosis and no plaque. Could the sprain have caused that decreased flow? After three months, it became normal again. Then, while having pedicure the woman massaged my ankle and leg. Since then the pain has returned to my left ankle and left leg. I had another D-dimer done three weeks ago that was negative. I have also recently started experiencing cold left foot and a left cold lower leg at night. By morning, both the legs as well as the feet are of the same temperature. I do get pain in the buttocks and the pain is going down my leg like a sciatic pain on the left leg. Do I have peripheral artery disease? Could a blood clot be causing it? I have a four hours flight next week and I am worried about flying. Is it safe to fly? Would the arterial Doppler and D-dimer be able to tell if I have a blood clot in my artery? Or is a D-dimer just for the veins? My LDL was 10 points above normal in my last blood test. But, my doctor did not seem to be concerned as my HDL was high. I have attached the reports for your reference. Please help me.
answer: Hello! I understand your concern about your left leg pain and decreased flow in the left anterior tibial artery. The arterial Doppler ultrasound and D-dimer test are reliable diagnostic tests for identifying arterial blood clots, particularly in the legs. The fact that your D-dimer test was negative, along with no stenosis and sclerosis seen on your Doppler ultrasound, makes it unlikely that you have peripheral artery disease or a blood clot. The previous talofibular ligament sprain could have caused the decreased flow, but it is encouraging that it returned to normal after three months. It is good to hear that you do not have any major risk factors for peripheral artery disease. However, since you are still experiencing some pain and coldness in your left leg and foot, it would be best to have a follow-up with your doctor or a vascular specialist for a more thorough evaluation. Pain in your buttocks that goes down your leg similar to sciatic pain could be related to a nerve or disc issue rather than arterial disease. Additional tests such as nerve conduction studies, nerve root imaging, or a CT or MRI scan of your lumbar spine may be required to better understand the cause of your symptoms. It is safe to fly for the majority of people with peripheral artery disease, as long as precautions are taken to avoid deep vein thrombosis (DVT). Steps you can take to minimize the risk of developing DVT while flying include walking around every hour, doing exercises while seated, staying adequately hydrated, and wearing compression stockings. You should discuss your travel plans with your doctor to determine if flying poses any risk in your specific case. Lastly, while high LDL cholesterol can contribute to the development of peripheral artery disease, it is not the sole cause. Other risk factors, such as hypertension and smoking, can also contribute to the development of the disease. Therefore, keeping your overall cardiovascular risk factors under control is essential in preventing peripheral arterial disease. I hope this information helps you!

prompt: Hello doctor,I am a young woman and I recently discovered that I am HIV positive after I turned 21. However, my major concern is that I have recently been having drowsiness spells and frequent, almost consistent headaches though they are very light. An FBC test done a month ago showed that my Hb and HCT, as well as my neutrophil count, were slightly below normal, and I was advised to go on a month of Saferon tablets which I followed religiously. Recent full blood tests showed that my RBC, Hb, HCT, MCV, and MCH values were all now slightly below normal whilst all my WBC were within the normal range. The Hb and HCT went lower than the initial test.Therefore, my questions are, might this be related to my HIV positive status and how so? Also if it is, why is it that my white blood cells are not affected? I am mostly curious about whether such an instance as mine is quite common where a patient is born with HIV and lives an otherwise normal livelihood though with more frequent infections that go away after some time?I really do hope to hear from you. I am now 22 and have accepted my condition and forgiven my parents. I am trying to, however, get as much information and understanding about my condition hence contacting you. I sincerely thank you for your time.
answer: Hello, I am sorry to hear about your diagnosis and also the fact that your parents did not tell you about your HIV status earlier. To answer your questions, yes, your low blood counts may be related to your HIV infection. HIV affects the immune system and can cause a decrease in the production of red blood cells and other blood components leading to anemia, which is the condition where the levels of hemoglobin and hematocrit are low. It can also lead to a decrease in the production of white blood cells, which are key to fighting infections, leading to an increased risk of infections. However, not all patients with HIV will have these symptoms. Regarding your question about why your white blood cell counts are normal, it is hard to say without knowing more details about your condition. However, it is possible for the white blood cell counts to remain normal in some HIV positive individuals for a while before decreasing further. It is not uncommon for patients with HIV to live normal lives, especially when on antiretroviral therapy (ART). With proper medical care and adherence to ART, HIV positive patients can live long and healthy lives. It is important for you to start ART and work closely with your healthcare team to manage your condition and prevent any complications. You do not need to be ashamed or afraid to seek help and start treatment. Your healthcare team is bound by confidentiality and will not disclose your status to anyone else without your permission. I hope that helps. Please do not hesitate to contact me if you have any further questions or concerns.

prompt: Hi doctor,When crossing a bar, I come across people smoking marijuana. Would a person test will be positive on hair or urine drug test in any situation? I am not a drug user.

prompt: Hello doctor,I was taking Doxycycline for three months. After I got a haircut in third month, I noticed that I had two bald patches (it is not actually bald, they were just super thin with a little bit of hair). I got a haircut again today, and the same problem occurred. I am almost positive that the problem is alopecia areata, and I also have the symptom of nail dystrophy (it appeared around two weeks ago). Do you think Doxycycline caused this issue? How can AA be treated, and how long should I expect for my bald spots to have normal thickness again?
answer: Hello! Doxycycline is not typically associated with alopecia areata (AA), which is an autoimmune disorder that causes hair loss in small, round patches. However, it is possible that the medication could have triggered an autoimmune reaction in your body, which led to the development of AA. The treatment of AA usually involves topical or injectable corticosteroids to reduce inflammation and promote hair regrowth. Other options may include topical immunotherapy, which stimulates an allergic reaction on the scalp to help regrow hair, or oral immunosuppressive medications, which are generally reserved for more severe or widespread cases of AA. The duration of treatment and the time it takes for hair to regrow varies widely among individuals and depends on the extent and severity of hair loss. In general, it can take several months to a year or more for hair to regrow fully, and even then, there is a risk of recurrence. I would recommend consulting with a dermatologist or hair loss specialist for a proper diagnosis and treatment plan. They may suggest some tests to rule out other possible causes of hair loss, such as thyroid disorders or fungal infections. I hope this helps, and I wish you all the best in your journey towards regaining your hair growth!

prompt: Hello doctor,My question is about a septoplasty operation for anesthesia. Doctor says I need this operation but I am scared of the anesthesia.
